name: MySQL
title: MySQL

children.text: MySQL is an open-source relational database management system. With the MySQL app in
, you can run your custom logic directly on your database server through stored procedures.
loads the interface of input and output parameters and record sets dynamically so each parameter/value can be mapped individually.
To use the MySQL app in
, you must have a MySQL server connection and a configured MySQL server.
To get started, you must first create a connection between MySQL and
, allowing the two services to communicate.
To create the connection, you need to:
privilege must be granted on the MySQL server.
Set the read access to MySQL tables
Make sure the account you are using to connect to your database has read access to the
Make will make connections to your database from the

data.label: Allow connections to and from Make IP addresses
data.overridedLabel: IP addresses listed in this article.

children.text: Our servers are set up with valid PTR records, so you can easily restrict access by allowing
Enable incoming TCP connections to port
(by adding a hash at the beginning of the line):
Create and grant remote access to your MySQL account
CREATE USER <user>@'%' IDENTIFIED BY <password> GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON <database>.* TO <user>@'%' IDENTIFIED BY <password> WITH GRANT OPTION; FLUSH PRIVILEGES;
Set the tolerance of non-interactive connection
modules that support transactions have open transactions throughout the whole run of a
. Therefore, make sure that you have set a long enough time to tolerate non-interactive connections. This MySQL command will list the values:
MySQL documentation on Server System Variables
Once you have configured your MySQL server, you're ready to create the connection in
field, enter a name for the connection.
Enter the name of the new MySQL connection you want to establish.
Enter the address of the MySQL server.
The MySQL server must be publicly accessible from the internet. If you want to use the database hosted on your local server, you'll need to specify your
" or "127.0.0.1" in this field, as it will not work.
Enter the port number of the MySQL server.
Enter the database name if needed. This is required for the
Enter the MySQL server user name.
Enable this option to connect to MySQL instances that use the old authentication method (MySQL 4.0 and older). If needed, see additional information about

file) if you want to use TLS using your self-signed certificate. If you're using the client-side certificate authorization, you can enter your CA certificate here.
does not retain or store any data (files, passwords) you provide. File and password are only used to extract a private key/certificate.
Upload the private key to use the client-side certificate authorization.
does not retain or store any data (files, passwords) you provide. File and password are only used to extract a private key/certificate.
Upload your certificate if you want to use client-side certificate authorization.
does not retain or store any data (files, passwords) you provide. File and password are only used to extract a private key/certificate.
If prompted, authenticate your account and confirm access.
You've successfully created the connection and can now use the MySQL app in your
. If you want to make changes to your connection in the future, follow the steps
After connecting to the MySQL app, you can use the following types of modules to build your
Deletes a row according to a defined filter.
Establish a connection to the MySQL server.
Select the table where you want to delete the row.
Set the filter for the row to be deleted.
Set filter values. You can also use logical operators, AND/OR, to specify your selection.
Establish a connection to the MySQL server.
Enter the desired MySQL query. Make sure that the
Variables used in the query are not sanitized. Make sure you sanitize variables properly to prevent SQL injection.
Continue the execution of the route even if the module returns no results
will not be stopped by this module.
Only one SQL statement is allowed (one semicolon
as a statement terminator per query).
Establish a connection to the MySQL server.
Select the stored procedure you want to execute. The stored procedure must already be created.
Here is a sample SQL statement that creates a stored procedure that simply inserts the values passed in the three parameters into a table:
DELIMITER ;; CREATE PROCEDURE `insert_record_from_integromat`(IN _name text, IN _email text, IN _phone text)
BEGIN INSERT INTO contacts (name, email, phone) VALUES (_name, _email, _phone); END;;
Contains the parameter fields from the stored procedure. E.g., enter values you want to insert into the table during the stored procedure execution.
The following example adds 2 to the provided parameter (e.g., in the
module), and returns the result, together with the current date (can be further iterated using the
Iterate Recordset of a Stored Procedure
Inserts a row with the desired values into a selected table.
Establish a connection to the MySQL server.
Select the table where you want to add a row.
Enter the desired values that will be inserted into the new row.
module. For more information, refer to

Enter the desired values that will be inserted into the rows.

children.text: Passing NULL Values into a Table
Pass NULL values into a table
As of now, it is not possible to pass NULL values in our standard modules,
To achieve this, you need to use the
module where you prepare a full SQL statement (either INSERT or UPDATE) as a workaround as shown in the example.
You need to update an existing row in your database with three columns: Name, Email, and Phone Number.
You want to update a contact and set the contact's phone to NULL based on the contact’s email address.
To achieve that, use this statement:
, map the email address (and the name possibly too) from preceding modules and ensure the mapped pills are in single quotes.
Selects a row from a table according to a defined filter.
Establish a connection to the MySQL server.
Select the table you want to select a row from.
Set the filter for the row to be selected.
Set filter values. You can also use logical operators, AND/OR, to specify your selection.
In the following MySQL dialog, the row that contains number 1 or 2 in the "column1" column will be selected.
Continue the execution of the route even if the module returns no results
will not be stopped by this module.
You may also use the existing basic text operators for
Just use text formatted date/datetime as the second operand:
Iterate recordset of a stored procedure
Select the source module containing the stored procedure recordset you want to iterate.
Error: ER_NOT_SUPPORTED_AUTH_MODE: Client does not support authentication protocol requested by server; consider upgrading MySQL client
MySQL 8 uses an authentication method that is not supported by
plugin to make the account fall back to the "traditional" process during the handshake, keeping compatibility by default for any previously supported server version.
CREATE USER 'new_user'@'%' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'user_password';
Or, modify the existing user account, and specify the
ALTER USER 'root'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'YourRootPassword';
Error: ER_LOCK_WAIT_TIMEOUT: Lock wait timeout exceeded; try restarting transaction
This error occurs when you modify the same data using multiple modules. It is caused by SQL transactions.
When any MySQL module is executed, then it starts the transaction (1), and the transaction is finished after the

is fully executed. If another module tries to access the same data used in another unfinished transaction (1), then it has to wait until the previous transaction (1) is finished. This, however, never happens because the first transaction (1) will be finished when the
. It finishes (commits) every transaction immediately after the module execution is done.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
